turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Where's the name sheet?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Nobody's named this one yet.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: It's my turn!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: He doesn't like it.  He's a boy, That's why.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Can't a boy be a Dorrit?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: You do it then.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Henceforth you shall be... Little Wilbur.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: I'm not crazy about the "Little..."

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Okay, he's just a Wilbur then.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: We haven't had a Wilbur here in a year or so, have we? We used to have *dozens*!

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: I thought you took care of this. It always breaks in the same place. It's your splice, isn't it?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: It's *your* splice! You blame me for everything!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I thought it was my turn.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: It is. I'll get this. You go ahead.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: How about expecting people to be responsible enough to control themselves to begin with?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: How about this child? You expect *her* to be responsible?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: It's just a marvel to me that you still have such high expectations of people.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I'm happy I amuse you.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Try to look at it this way. What choice does Buster have? What are his options? Nobody will ever adopt him.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Try to look at it *this* way. Buster and I are sitting right here beside you. We could have ended up in the incinerator!

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Happy to be alive, under any circumstances--is that your point?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Doubtless you'll let me know what immensely worthwhile or at least *useful* thing it is that you find to do.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I wasn't intending to leave here in order to be entirely useless--I expect I'll find some ways to be of use.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: In other parts of the world, I suppose there are other ways.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Are you really so *stupid* that you imagine you're going to find a more gratifying life? What you're going to find is people like the poor people who get left here--only nobody takes care of them as well! And you won't be able to take care of them, either. There's no taking care of *anybody*-- not out there!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: You know I'm grateful for everything you've done for me...

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: I don't need your gratitude.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I don't need this--I know all about my condition.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: It's your heart--you ought to take it with you.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I am not a doctor.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: You know everything I know, plus what you've taught yourself--you're a better doctor then I am and you know it!

turns.speaker: OLIVE
turns.text: What I mean is... I would like it very much if you thought you could be happy here, Homer.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Mrs. Worthington, I feel I'm very lucky to be here.

turns.speaker: OLIVE
turns.text: There's not a lot of work in the winter, and you'll have to tolerate Vernon--even Wally despises him, and Wally likes everyone.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I think Wally will be fine, Mrs. Worthington--he seems indestructible to me.

turns.speaker: OLIVE
turns.text: I don't know.  Just promise me one thing.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Uh... sure.

turns.speaker: OLIVE
turns.text: Just promise me that, if there's a blizzard, you'll move into Wally's room until it's over.

turns.speaker: OLIVE
turns.text: Good-bye, Arthur.  Homer, I'll see you tomorrow?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: Don't mess in this, Homer, if you know what's good for you.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: How long's this been going on, Muddy?

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: Long enough. You ain't gonna stop it.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: "One: Please don't smoke in bed."

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: We heard that one already, Homer.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: "Two: Please don't go up to the roof to eat your lunch."

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Thanks, guys... I'd like to go with you. But I've got to move on.

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: Yeah, well... you could move on with *us*, man! You could move on somewhere *warm*!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Rose Rose?

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: Pretty, ain't it? You a plumber?

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: It's just my heart.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: What you got a picture of your heart for?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: There's a little something wrong with it. Just this part here--the right ventricle. It's slightly enlarged.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: So what?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Yes, so what. It's nothing serious, really. Just a small defect.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Do you like to read?

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: I can't read. Nobody taught me.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: You ain't gettin' in no trouble, I hope.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: No trouble.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I'm not in trouble.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: Yeah, you is. I know when people is in trouble, and you is.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Give men that. I know how to do it.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: Oh, I suppose you is a doctor, Homer?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Almost.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: You okay, Rose?

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: I guess you must like watchin' me be sick...

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I don't like watching anyone be sick.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: You're not yet three months, are you?

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: Not yet. What do you know about it?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I know more than I want to know about it. Who's the father?

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: Don't trouble yourself about it, Homer--this ain't your business.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: But you don't look very happy.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: *Happy*! What are you thinkin'? How am I supposed to take care of a baby! I can't have a baby.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Rose, please listen. Whatever you want to do, I can help you.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: What I mean is, if you don't want to... keep the baby, I know a place where you can go.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: You think Daddy's gonna let me go anywhere? I ain't going *nowhere*.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: Why don't you just go back to your pickin', Homer? I can take care of it myself!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Rose, listen--don't *do* anything. You know, I mean to yourself. Please listen...

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: That's *it*?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: That's it.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: It means nothin' at all! And all this time I been *wonderin'* about it!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Who cares?

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Now, now. He's a good boy.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Shit. We don't know what he is.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Jack, you gotta watch your language 'round my daughter.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I bet the view looks better from the Worthin'tons'.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: You think so, Jack? Well... I wouldn't want to be in that Wally's shoes tonight.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: That just ain't right, Jack--your cigarette's gonna end up in nine or ten gallons of this batch of cider! That ain't right.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Them people drinkin' that cider, they don't know there's a cigarette in there!

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: It's not that hard to find it in there, Jack--it'll take you just a minute. You just gotta go fishin'.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You mean *swimmin'*. I ain't goin' in that vat to fish out no cigarette!

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: What business is you in, Jack? Just tell me what your business is...

turns.speaker: MRS. GOODHALL
turns.text: Do you know him?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: *No*! I don't want to know him! He's doing *missionary* work--in *India*! I wrote him *weeks* ago, but he's either too holy or too busy to answer. Maybe he got killed in the war!

turns.speaker: MRS. GOODHALL
turns.text: I fail to see how someone courageous enough to make a commitment to a foreign mission is automatically to be dismissed--that part of the world requires precisely the kind of dedication that is needed here.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Does it *snow* in Bombay? One winter here and we'll be shipping him south, in a *coffin*!

turns.speaker: MRS. GOODHALL
turns.text: You can't think that a man who has *served* under such conditions as exist over there will be in the slightest daunted by a little *snow*-- have you no idea how harsh and primitive and full of *disease* that part of the world is?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Then I suppose we can look forward to catching various diseases from him!

turns.speaker: MRS. GOODHALL
turns.text: I fail to see how a little Christianity could *hurt* anyone here!

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Anyway, I was just showing you this guy as an example of what's available-- I didn't think you'd be interested.

turns.speaker: MAJOR WINSLOW
turns.text: When the plane was hit, the crew chief and the radioman jumped close together. The copilot jumped third. All on Captain Worthington's orders-- the captain was still flying the plane. None of the men of the ground could see the sky--that's how thick the jungle was. They never saw the plane crash--they never *heard* it crash. They never saw Captain Worthington's parachute, either.

turns.speaker: OLIVE
turns.text: Why was he missing for twenty days?

turns.speaker: MAJOR WINSLOW
turns.text: Because the crew thought he'd gone down with the plane. They were hospitalized for almost a week in China before they were flown back to India. It wasn't until that they sorted through their gear...

turns.speaker: OLIVE
turns.text: Then it's malaria?

turns.speaker: MAJOR WINSLOW
turns.text: It's encephalitis B. He's recovering at Mount Lavinia Hospital, Ceylon.  Uh... Captain Worthington is paralyzed.  Waist down. He won't walk.

turns.speaker: MAJOR WINSLOW
turns.text: No autonomic effects... that's correct.

turns.speaker: OLIVE
turns.text: When will he be home, Major?

turns.speaker: MAJOR WINSLOW
turns.text: Four weeks or so, right around Halloween.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: They told me I was too old to serve.

turns.speaker: PEACHES
turns.text: They told Muddy his feet was too flat!

turns.speaker: PEACHES
turns.text: Ain't you gonna see what it is, Homer?

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Mind your own business, Peaches.

turns.speaker: PEACHES
turns.text: Sorry, Homer...

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: You all take care of yourself, too, Homer!

turns.speaker: PEACHES
turns.text: We see you next harvest.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Don't this place look like home?

turns.speaker: PEACHES
turns.text: It look nicer then home!

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: What have you two been doin' to make it look so nice?

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: You pickin' nothin' but cider apples, Peaches--I hope you understand that.

turns.speaker: PEACHES
turns.text: They ain't drops--I picked 'em off the tree!

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Then you pickin' 'em too fast--they ain't no better than drops to me. See that bruise, and that one? *Half* of these is bruised! Look at this one! It ain't got no stem! You might as well *step* on 'em, too--they only good for cider.

turns.speaker: PEACHES
turns.text: They're *outrageous*, them rules!

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Who *live* here in this cider house, Peaches? Who grind them apples, who press that cider, who clean up the mess, and who just plain *live* here... just breathin' in the vinegar?  Somebody who *don't* live here made them rules. Them rules ain't for *us*. *We* the ones who make up them rules. We makin' our *own* rules, every day. Ain't that right, Homer?

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Where's your manners? Make room for Homer, so's he can enjoy the view.

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: What view?

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: *What* view?

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Well, Muddy, we can look at all these angry stars Homer's been readin' to us about.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Don't let us make you nervous or nothin'--we know you gotta job to do.

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: Yeah, we can wait all night for the water to come back on--you just go on and take your time.

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: It's that Vernon--he keeps askin' where you and Homer and Rose Rose is at.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Tell that Vernon to mind his own business, Muddy.

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: I told him that you all is sick.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Tell him what you want, Muddy--*you* is the crew boss today.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: She's *good* with that knife! She's real fast. She's a lot better with that knife than *you* is, Muddy! And who do you suppose taught her?

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: *You* taught her, I suppose...

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: That's right! A girl's gotta know how to defend herself, don't she?

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: That what happen--you lost you only daughter so's you killed yourself! That's what we say, all right.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: That's right. I know you understand how I feel, Homer--you is breakin' them rules, too. Ain't that right?

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: Daddy, I'd like to be in that Wally's shoes *every* night.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: You lucky you in your work boots tonight, girl...

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: What's lucky about that?

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: That sounds like you is in trouble already, Homer.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: That's right--that sounds like trouble to me.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: We should drown that damn Jack in the vat!

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Now, now, darlin'... Jack just needs to know what business he's in.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: Yeah, you really showed him, Daddy-- you just about cut your own hand off, and all you cut off *him* was his clothes!

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: You oughta know you don't go to jail for cuttin' a guy's *clothes*. Ain't that right, Homer?

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Now, now, Jack--that just ain't right.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: You just stay out of trouble, Homer!

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Where do you think you're going?

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: You gotta let me go, Daddy. Please...

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: You ain't goin' nowhere in the middle of the night, girl!

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: I ain't your business no more, Daddy. Please let me go.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: You just go inside, Homer. We don't need no help.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: That's right, Homer. This ain't your business.

turns.speaker: PEACHES
turns.text: That Candy--she's the nicest girl I know!

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: She's about the most beautiful girl I ever seen--I don't know if she's the nicest.

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: You're lucky he didn't cut your *nipples* off, man.

turns.speaker: PEACHES
turns.text: The good news, Jack, is you're half- undressed for *swimmin'*...

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: Yeah, that cigarette ain't hard to find when you're properly undressed.

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: Rose Rose has runned away!

turns.speaker: PEACHES
turns.text: She took off in the night!

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: She took off on the bicycle, man.

turns.speaker: MUDDY
turns.text: You ever see a palm tree, Homer?

turns.speaker: PEACHES
turns.text: He ain't never been outta Maine!

turns.speaker: LILY
turns.text: But I'm not that late. You didn't have to give away my seat.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: I wasn't sure if you'd make it.

turns.speaker: LILY
turns.text: Thanks for playing along. I just have to sit for a while.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Tough day?

turns.speaker: LILY
turns.text: Brutal day. They say the streets are lined with money down here, but I guess you have to know the secret handshake. What are you drinking?

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Uh, Maker's Mark. Rocks.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: My name's Grant. Grant Ashby.

turns.speaker: LILY
turns.text: Oh god. I'm overbearing and rude. Lily. Lily Finn.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: So, what do you do?

turns.speaker: LILY
turns.text: It's more like what aren't I doing. My partners and I are trying to secure start up capital for a small tech company. We tried the venture capitalist route in the Valley, but then again who hasn't up there.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Silicon Valley?

turns.speaker: LILY
turns.text: That's right. So, brainiacs that we are, we thought we'd be innovative and relocate east. Try our luck with a straight corporate loan out here.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Can --

turns.speaker: LILY
turns.text: On me. For the seat. Cheers.

turns.speaker: LILY
turns.text: So we've been meeting with banks all day. It's amazing how many ways they can say "no" without ever using the word.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Well, typically, corporate loans are relatively simple matters, but you do need to demonstrate a capacity for gross fund recovery.

turns.speaker: LILY
turns.text: Don't tell me you started a tech firm here before us.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: No, no. Nothing like that. I work in a bank.

turns.speaker: LILY
turns.text: Really? Wish we had met eight hours ago.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Oh. Well, thanks for the drink.

turns.speaker: LILY
turns.text: You're welcome. I was just going to ask you if you'd like to join us.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Uh, right... And that was it. That's when we decided to start our own business. No more shithead bosses.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: I envy you guys. Taking a chance like that.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What do you do over at your bank, Grant?

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: What do I do? I'm the VP of Finance.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Here's where a little research comes in handy. Corporate banks give out VP titles like calendars. It's a small lie, but now we're sure he's playing.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Maybe you can help us understand what's so hard about getting a corporate loan.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Well, typically speaking, they're not. As long as you can demonstrate --

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: A capacity for gross fund recovery. Yeah, we got that part.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: That's right. And tech firms... They 'tend to scare people off.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: They scare people off because most people lack vision. Vision and balls. Present company excluded of course.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Banks need to know how they're going to get their money back.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: We know exactly how we're going to make the money back. There in lies the Catch-22

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: I don't follow.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Listen, what I'm about to tell you, I'm telling you in confidence, okay?  Have you ever heard of a company called Big.Com?

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Big.Com. That Internet thing.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Right. The guys who started that did what a lot of companies in the Valley do. They get a good idea, shop it around, raise some capital, then sell it off to a bigger company. Microsoft, Intel, Oracle, whatever. The beauty of it is, they've pretty much sold the company before they're even real. The bigger company is already set to buy it, all they want to do is make sure that the idea actually works. So they get some start up capital, make it work, then sell it for like five times the initial loan.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Sort of like a letter of intent.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Exactly. But the Catch-22 is that you can't tell anyone about the offer, because if it's public, you could start a bidding war and that's considered a breach of etiquette. It could kill a deal. But, wait too long and you're not considered hot anymore.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: And you have this letter of intent?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Yes. That's why I wish there were guys willing to take a chance and live a little.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: We had to finalize the deal.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Everything looks in order.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: This has to happen fast.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: I know. It won't go unnoticed.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: There'll be red flags.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You need some convincing. Consider it a convincer.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Let's just slow down for a second...

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You're worried about recouping the loan. I already told you.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: No, I understand that. What I mean... What I'm trying to say... I was actually wondering about... Well, my cut.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Then there it is. Ashby gets the itch.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: The standard ten.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Ten percent. Of how much?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Two million.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Same thing with playing a con. You have to be able to see that deep.

turns.speaker: ASHBY
turns.text: Jake? Right. Uh-huh... Uh-huh... Yeah, it's going through --

turns.speaker: BIG AL
turns.text: Hey, Jake... When am I gonna get to play the Inside?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Gordo plays the inside. You're the Shill.

turns.speaker: BIG AL
turns.text: Yeah, but come on... All I get to do is cry and get insulted.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What are you talking about? You should get a fucking Academy Award for the Shill work you do.  We got it down cold, Al. You don't want to jinx it by changing something up, do you?

turns.speaker: BIG AL
turns.text: I'm gonna go get eggrolls. Anyone want eggrolls?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: It can erase all those things about you that you wish didn't exist.

turns.speaker: BIG AL
turns.text: It's Alfonse. I want to settle up. I haven't been ducking you. I told you I'd get it.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: And I think it's because of this redhead...

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Know who I am, Jake?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: The Anti-Christ?

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: No. I'm not the Anti-Christ. Or the Prince of Darkness. I'm just a guy looking for some answers.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Things are probably going to end badly for you, Jake.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Gee... What makes you say that?

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Your life flashing before your eyes?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Just the last three weeks.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: That's not a bad place to start.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Grifters...

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: We can't all be model citizens such as yourself.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: It's all about the money, isn't it?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Isn't it always?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: I'm not saying anything. Besides, you're one to talk. You're the one who's got me on my knees in a dark alley.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: And these cops? What do they get?

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Keeping the Fix happy.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You never know when you can use a crooked cop.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Keep going. I want to know how you got Lionel Dolby.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: So you want to know how to play the Big Con.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: In this case, you might say I want to know how not to play the Big Con.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: So how'd you get caught?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Suits used to say that in any con, sooner or later someone's going to start asking the right questions. Usually, it takes a little longer.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: I can see why you liked her.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: That was it. We had our crew. Now we needed the Mark.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: But there were other factors.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Factors that weren't clear to me until now.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: He's just as crooked as the next guy. You'd think he'd have more important things to do with tax payer dollars.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Cue the fucking violins. Come on... It's getting cold.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Nice.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: We got our stake. Now we need to find our guy in Gillett's bank.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Thanks. Did you know you shouldn't light three cigarettes with a match?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Back in WWI or WWII, one of the WW's, if you took the time to light three cigarettes with one match, some Nazi would be able to figure out where you were. Then, well... It was the last cigarette you and your two buddies ever had. So three on a match is bad luck.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: You're a superstitious fucker.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Luck's a funny thing. Especially the bad.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Having a gun pointed at you for one. It's not like breaking a mirror bad luck, but it's bad. Three on a match, black cats... Believe it. Believe it all.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: She had you tempting fate.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: My father used to play the same fucking lotto numbers with these other guys in the pharmacy. The same numbers everyday for sixteen years. One day he gets pissed off, tells them he's out and plays his own numbers. They hit the Lucky Seven for one point two million.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Is that what it was, Jake? Was it love?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You know when the first con was ever played? It was when Adam fell for Eve in the Garden of Eden.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: So much for honor among thieves. You would have cut loose your friends, your girl...

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: I was doing it for them.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: BULLSHIT! You were scared, Jake! You lost your nerve! You lost your confidence! You weren't being noble. You weren't trying to save anybody but yourself! Admit it.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: It's not true.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Yes it is, Jake! Yes it is! They were right there for you. She was right there for you! Look at her!

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: We were back on.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: After you cut her loose.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: She walked.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Alrlght, alrlght. What happened today?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Today? Started off great...

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Alright... Turn around. She doesn't get shit, unless I get that money. Where is it?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Probably safe in the hands of the Federal Government.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Oh, Jake. You disappoint me. And you just let Lily here down again. What was it you said about playing the big con?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: It's like putting on a play, where everyone knows their part except for the mark.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Like putting on a play... Guess some people forgot their lines.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Guess so.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: So why don't you take a deep breath, Jake, and I'll count to ten. One. Two. Three...

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: Not that I recall. What do you want us to do about it?

turns.speaker: GILLETTE
turns.text: Let's see... Let's suppose he gets to Customs and he gets caught. We get our money back, but then we have to deal with a criminal investigation. I don't much like that idea. Then again, let's suppose he actually gets through Customs. Now, that'll be something. We recover the money in cash and let the insurance cover the corporate fraud. We double our money.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: So we go to the bar.

turns.speaker: GILLETTE
turns.text: I think so. The airport's going to be crawling with police. Traffic will be a nightmare. Go down to the bar. If they pull it off, great. Have someone deal with Ashby.

turns.speaker: BUTCH
turns.text: We'll take care of it.

turns.speaker: GILLETTE
turns.text: And how much did you say you wanted for this... What did you call it? A finder's fee?
